byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Rick Gladstone from New York, Eric Schmitt from Washington, and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon.

abstract: Backlash of anti-American sentiment appears to be forming in Iran following passage of historic nuclear agreement, countering any expectation of gradually warming relations between countries; backlash comes as Iran is preparing for elections that will prove test of Pres Hassan Rouhani's policies and as hard-liners seek to quell hopes of political liberalization.
lead_paragraph: Arrests of suspected American spies, anti-American billboards, and even the abrupt closure of a knockoff K.F.C. restaurant have signaled a backlash.

headline.main: Backlash Against U.S. in Iran Seems to Gather Force After Nuclear Deal
headline.print_headline: Backlash Against U.S. Seems to Gather Force in Iran

snippet: Arrests of suspected American spies, anti-American billboards, and even the abrupt closure of a knockoff K.F.C. restaurant have signaled a backlash.
